sentences: Mitsuo Terada (寺田 光男, born October 29, 1968), known by his stage name Tsunku (つんく, often written as つんく♂), is a Japanese record producer, songwriter, and vocalist.
section: N/A

sentences: He is known for being very prolific.
section: N/A

sentences: Total sales of the singles he has written exceed 37.9 million copies, making him the fifth best-selling lyricist in Japan.
section: N/A

sentences: Tsunku is best known for having two major roles in the Japanese music landscape: first as the lead singer of the popular rock group Sharam Q, and now as the producer, primary composer, lyricist, and (until 2014) primary studio backing vocalist for highly popular idol group Morning Musume, in addition to Aya Matsuura and other associated idols under the Hello! Project banner, for whom he has written and produced the vast majority of their chart-topping hits.
section: N/A

sentences: He has also produced music for other Japanese artists, including Ayumi Hamasaki's first number one single.
section: N/A

sentences: As his musical influences he cites The Beatles, Japanese popular music (especially kayōkyoku), American and European hits being played on the radio when he was a schoolboy, disco acts such as Chic, Kool & the Gang and Earth, Wind & Fire, and bands like Duran Duran and The Power Station.
section: N/A

sentences: He is mostly known outside of Japan for creating the Nintendo video game series Rhythm Tengoku/Rhythm Heaven.
section: N/A
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In June 2006, Tsunku married Kanako Idemitsu (出光 加奈子), a 25-year-old former model from Fukuoka.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The couple have fraternal twins (one boy and one girl, the girl's more known debut name being Hotzmic) born in 2008 and one daughter who was born in 2011.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Tsunku later worked with Nintendo and J.P. ROOM to create the music video game, Rhythm Tengoku.

sentences: It was released for the Game Boy Advance exclusively in Japan on August 3, 2006, and later as an arcade machine on September 20, 2007.
section: == History ==

sentences: He also worked on Rhythm Tengoku Gold (Released in the US as Rhythm Heaven and in Europe as Rhythm Paradise) for the Nintendo DS, Minna no Rhythm Tengoku (Rhythm Heaven Fever in the US, Beat the Beat: Rhythm Paradise in Europe) for the Wii, and Rhythm Tengoku: The Best Plus (Rhythm Heaven Megamix in the US, Rhythm Paradise Megamix in Europe) for the Nintendo 3DS.
section: == History ==

sentences: Some of his works in the late 2000s were particularly mature and hard-hitting (considering the ages of the girls singing them), such as the Morning Musume singles "Kanashimi Twilight, "Onna ni Sachi Are" and "Resonant Blue".
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === Hello! Project ===

sentences: Although his own work as a soloist and in Sharam Q tends to lean towards pop-rock, he is best known for working with various arrangers to create highly melodic, richly-textured sequencer-driven electronic dance music which often features synthesizers, as well as guitar riffs and solos which sometimes hint at hard rock or heavy metal influences (such as in Morning Musume's "Ambitious!
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === Hello! Project ===

sentences: Typical vocal arrangements in the songs he writes for Hello!
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === Hello! Project ===

sentences: Project's groups tend to revolve around the members taking turns at singing lines and sometimes even small parts of lines in succession, building up to a chorus in which most (if not all) members sing in unison rather than using vocal harmonies; any harmonies that are present in the songs are often sung by other people (including Tsunku himself, who records his backing vocals so as to appear to sing "along with" the girls on their studio recordings during key parts of songs such as during choruses and on certain phrases, in a voice an octave lower than theirs).
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === Hello! Project ===

sentences: However, there have been some exceptions, such as the Morning Musume songs "Morning Coffee", "Furusato", "Memory Seishun no Hikari", "Love Machine" and "I Wish", where most (if not all) of the backing vocals were sung by the group's members themselves.
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === Hello! Project ===

sentences: As a result of the Japanese earthquake in 2011, Tsunku wrote a song titled Love is Here ~Kibou no Hikari~, dedicated to the victims.
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === 2011 – present ===

sentences: Tsunku is one of the many Japanese celebrities who have stepped up to support the victims and their loved ones.
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === 2011 – present ===

sentences: In March 2014, Tsunku announced on his blog that he had laryngeal cancer, which he found out after having throat surgery due to an unspecified condition.
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === 2011 – present ===

sentences: He also stated that he has been seeking treatment for it.
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === 2011 – present ===

sentences: On April 4, 2015, Tsunku revealed that he had his vocal cords removed as part of his cancer treatment.
section: == Music composition and lyrical works == | === 2011 – present ===

sentences: In his memoir, Dakara, Ikiru, which was published in September 2015, it was revealed that he stepped down as Hello!
